Ancestry.com, Obituary Collection - Charleston Daily Mail, Charleston WV, 11 Jul 2006:

Mr. Lyndon Doyle Ball was born on Nov. 29, 1964, in Madison. Lennie, as known to most, passed away unexpectedly on Monday, June 5, 2006.

He was preceded in death by his father, Richard Lee Ball and his stepmother, Georgia Garrison Ball.

Lennie graduated from Parkland High School in 1983. He went on to join the NASCAR circuit as a fabricator. He was a member of Matt Kenseth's 2003 Winston Cup Championship team. Lennie was a beloved son, brother, uncle, and friend and will be greatly missed by all.

He is survived by two sisters, Rhonda Hill and Janice Davis; two brothers, Gary and Dean Ball of North Carolina; and five uncles, Billy Lowe, Jimmy, Charlie, Frank, and Elbert Ball of West Virginia.

A graveside service will be at 10 a.m. Friday, July 14, at Memory Gardens, Madison, with Minister Cliff Collins officiating.

Memorials may be directed to Handley Funeral Home, P.O. Box 175, Danville, WV 25053.

Wikipedia - USAir Flight 427:

US Air Flight 427 was a scheduled flight from Chicago's O'Hare International Airport to Pittsburgh, with a final destination of West Palm Beach, Florida. The flight crashed on Thursday, September 8, 1994, killing everyone on board.

The Boeing 737-3B7 flying the route, registered N513AU, was approaching runway 28R of Pittsburgh International Airport, located in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania. The airport was, at the time, the largest hub for the airline.

CRASH

45-year-old Captain Peter Germano and 38-year-old First Officer Charles B. "Chuck" Emmett III piloted the aircraft. At about 6,000 feet (1,800 m) and 6 miles (10 km) from the runway, at 7:03PM, the aircraft experienced a sudden loss of control and slammed into the ground in an 80 degree nose down postion, while banked 60 degrees to the right, and traveling at 300mph in Hopewell Township, Beaver County, near Aliquippa, Pennsylvania, killing all 127 passengers and 5 crew members. The plane just barely missed the Aliquippa exit, which was crowded with cars full of people driving home from work.

Flight 427 has the third highest death toll of any aviation accident involving a Boeing 737-300 after the crash of Flash Airlines Flight 604 and China Southern Airlines Flight 3943. When it occurred, it was the second deadliest accident involving a Boeing 737 and is currently the sixth deadliest. It was also the seventh deadliest aviation disaster in the history of the United States at the time it occurred; as of 2012, it now ranks ninth.

INVESTIGATION

After the longest investigation in aviation history - more than four and a half years - the concluding statement said:

The National Transportation Safety Board determines that the probable cause of the USAir flight 427 accident was a loss of control of the airplane resulting from the movement of the rudder surface to its blowdown limit. The rudder surface most likely deflected in a direction opposite to that commanded by the pilots as a result of a jam of the main rudder power control unit servo valve secondary slide to the servo valve housing offset from its neutral position and overtravel of the primary slide.

The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that similar rudder problems caused the previously mysterious March 3, 1991 crash of United Airlines Flight 585, and the June 9, 1996 incident involving Eastwind Airlines Flight 517, both of which were Boeing 737s. As a result of the investigation, pilots were warned of and trained how to deal with insufficient aileron authority at an airspeed at or less than 190 knots (218 mph, 354 km/h), formerly the usual approach speed for a Boeing 737. Four additional channels of information-pilot rudder pedal commands-were incorporated into flight data recorders, while Boeing redesigned the rudder system on 737s and retrofitted existing craft until the affected systems could be replaced. The United States Congress also required airlines to deal more sensitively with the families of crash victims.

US Airways 427 is no longer a valid flight number on US Airways as of January 2011.

Flight 427 was the second fatal crash in a little over two months at the company (the other being USAir Flight 1016 at Charlotte-Douglas Airport in July 1994). The crashes contributed to the financial crisis USAir was experiencing at the time.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ancestry.com Obituary Collection - The Charleston Gazette - (Sep/2/2005)

Ralph L. Jarrell, 79, of Madison died Aug. 31, 2005, in CAMC Memorial Hospital, Charleston.

He was preceded in death by his mother and father, Carmel and Mabel Jarrell; brothers, Steve and Clell Jarrell and wife, Nell Jarrell.

He was a minister of the Church of Christ for 50 years and enjoyed preaching throughout Boone County and enjoyed preserving family history in overseeing cemetery monuments for Green Cemetery and Jarrell Cemetery of Bandytown and the Benjamin Price Cemetery generation of Price Hill. He was the present minister of the Church of Christ, Quinland. He retired from Peabody Coal Company and was a World War II Marine Corps veteran from July 5, 1944, until the war ended in October 1946.

He is survived by his wife, Angelina Jo Griffith Jarrell of Madison; daughters and their husbands, Connie and Ron Hough of Edgemoor, S.C., Debbie and Gene Taylor of Dunbar and Eunice and Mickey Brown of Madison; a son and his wife, Tim and Ann Jarrell of Dumfries, Va.; grandchildren, Jeremy Jarrell of Huntington, Jaime Stroud and husband, Anthony, of Edgemoor, S.C., Gary Sanders II and wife, Anna, of Fort Benning, Ga., Tara Sanders of Madison and Kent and Sam Jarrell, both of Dumfries, Va.; great-grandchildren, Blake Stroud of Edgemoor; sister, Arbitus Pauley of Parkersburg; and a brother, Victor Jarrell of Dunnellon, Fla.

Funeral service will be 2 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 3, at Handley Funeral Home, Danville, with ministers David Cabell and Richard Runyon officiating. Burial will follow in Memory Gardens, Madison, with military graveside rites by VFW Post 5578, Madison.

Friends may call from 6 to 9 p.m. Friday at the funeral home.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Notes for Freda June McClure:

Ancestry.com. Social Security Death Index [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations Inc, 2012. Original data: Social Security Administration. Social Security Death Index, Master File. Social Security Administration.

Freeda J Dolin, Born: 17 Jan 1933, Died: 1 Feb 2012, State (Year) SSN issued: West Virginia (Before 1951).

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ancestry.com. United States Obituary Collection [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations Inc. Herald-Dispatch, Huntington, West Virginia, 3 Feb 2012:.

FREEDA JUNE McCLURE-DOLIN, 79 years, of South Point, Ohio, went to be with the Lord on Wednesday, February 1, 2012. She was born January 17, 1933, in Madison, W.Va. Reunited with and preceding her in death were her parents Glen Evan and Geneva Ella Ball McClure and a baby brother Evan.

She is survived by her devoted husband of 60 years, Andrew Jackson Dolin. She leaves her love and blessings to her six children Glen and Kay Jeffrey Dolin of South Point, Ohio, Steve and Sharon Triplett Dolin of South Point, Ohio, Maurice and Judy Svarda Dolin of Middletown, Ohio, Fred and Frances Dolin Lewis of Kitts Hill, Ohio, Terry and Pat Byrd Dolin of South Point, Ohio and Rick and Shirley Dolin Snider of Barboursville, W.Va.; 18 grandchildren, Andrew, Candace, Jami, Amanda, Michael, Nathan, Kevin, Buddy, Laura, Jenafer, Alicia, Matthew, Johnathan, Ace, Terrina, Jennifer, Luke and Mark and 23 great-grandchildren.

Mommy's works were a testimony to her faithful obedient servanthood to GOD, worshipping Him as a member of the Kenova Church of Christ. Along her journey in life she embraced being a wife and mother continuing to raise her children "...in the way they should go..." Prov. 22:16. She enjoyed reading, crocheting, yard selling and the church's annual VBS. We can only imagine the smile on her face when she received her heavenly reward. She is now resting in the arms of her parents and our Lord. Our world has become dimmer, but heaven became a little brighter upon her arrival. We love you, Mommy.

The family wishes to invite you to celebrate her life with them by attending her visitation Friday, February 3rd from 6 to 8 p.m. and her memorial service Saturday, February 4th at noon, both to be held at Kenova Church of Christ, 1801 Chestnut Street, Kenova, W.Va. Brother Joe Pratt will be the speaker of her celebration. Upon conclusion of her service at Rose Hill Burial Park, Ashland, Ky., please return with the family and join us in a reception dinner hosted by the Kenova Church of Christ. Rollins Funeral Home in Kenova, is assisting the family Condolences may be extended to the family at www.rollinsfh.com.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Find A Grave - Herbert "Herb" Maloy:

HERB MALOY:

Herb Maloy killed in Scioto Mishap - Pike Township Trustee Died in Traffic Accident -- The death of Herbert E. (Herb) Maloy, 45, of Rt. 3 Waverly, involved in a traffic accident last Thursday evening near Portsmouth, Ohio, has been attributed to laceration of an abdominal blood vessel and subsequent hemorrhage. The ruling was given Monday by Dr. James F. Scott, Scioto County coroner, following an autopsy. Maloy, a Democratic precinct committee and Jackson Township trustee, was pronounced dead on arrival at Scioto Memorial Hospital following a chain-reaction, six-car accident on U. S. 23 just north of Portsmouth near the Club Franklin. Maloy's death was the seventh to result from Scioto County traffic accidents this year. Sheriff's Deputies Orland Leadingham and Carl Roth said the crash occurred when Maloy, who was driving a pickup truck south on U. S. 23, struck in the rear a car operated by Patricia Mullins, 20, of 818 Ninth St., Portsmouth. The Mullins car was stopped in the inside southbound lane preparing to turn into the parking lot at Club Franklin, deputies said. The Mullins car, crashed into the parking lot, which was jammed with cars, and struck a parked convertible owned by Harry McNeer, 1631 Carrol St. Also damaged in the crash were cars owned by Gerald McNamer of Lucasville, William Kessinger, 2431 Scioto Trail, and Dorothy M. Dotson of Lucasville Rt. 5. Witnesses removed Maloy from the truck immediately after the accident because of the danger of fire from a large quantity of gasoline spilled from the wrecked vehicle. He was taken to the hospital by Emrick ambulance. Maloy is survived by his wife, Mrs. Ruby Williams Maloy; his father, E. A. Maloy of Waverly, Rt. 3; two sons, Donald of Springfield and Alfred of Columbus, a daughter, Mrs. Boyd Fontaine of Aberdeen, Md.; a brother Paul of Waverly, Rt. 3; six sisters, Mrs. Willard Leffler, Mrs. Wilbey Bauer Jr., and Mrs. Walter Snyder, all of Waverly, Rt. 3, Mrs. Gib Breitenbach of Waverly, Mrs. A. J. Monts [sic, Mounts] of Springfield, and Mrs. Lional Evans of Waverly, Rt. 1; and three grandchildren. Funeral services were held at 2 p.m. Sunday at the Omega Church of Christ in Christian Union with Rev. Marion Conkel officiating. Burial was in the Omega Cemetery under the direction of Howe Co. Funeral Home.

Created by: Sherry (Tackett) Plowman; Record added: Apr 11, 2009; Find A Grave Memorial# 35750615:

Friends may call at the home of Donna's son Charlie Sunday , February 19, 2006, between 2 and 5 p.m. at 1525 Edgerton Avenue, Roanoke, Va. Ancestry.com. Web: Ohio, Find A Grave Index, 1803-2012 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2012 - Alfred V. "Bud" Maloy:

• Birth: unknown, Death: Dec. 13, 2012 in Columbus, Franklin County, Ohio, USA; Burial: Omega Cemetery, Omega, Pike County, Ohio, USA.

• Parents: Herbert Maloy (1922 - 1967) and Ruby Mae Williams Maloy (1912 - 1998).

OBITUARY:

Alfred V. "Bud" Maloy, 69, born, January 27, 1943 and passed away after a brave battle with cancer on December 13, 2012 in Columbus, OH.

He was preceded in death by his parents, Herbert and Ruby; sister, Erma "Sis"; and brother, Donald "Buck".

Bud is survived by his soul mate of 26 years, Sue Copley; son, Vinson; granddaughter, Kendra; favorite aunt, Fleita (Walter) Snyder; several nieces and nephews as well as Sue's extended family.

Graduated from Waverly HS in 1961; proudly served four years in the United States Air Force; was an avid NASCAR fan and also enjoyed golf, football and other sports. Bud was loved by many for his smile, sense of humor and best known for his BUD hat. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

Graveside Funeral Service and Military Honors PENDING FOR Saturday, December 29, 2012 at 1pm at Omega Cemetery, Omega, OH.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bud's memory to any cancer research or support facility of your choice.

Created by: JLM; Record added: May 30, 2009; Find A Grave Memorial# 37708925

Recption Oct 30

An open reception celebrating their 50th wedding anniversary will be held from 3 to 5 p.m. at Emmanuel Baptist Church, Washington Street W, honoring Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A Frame Sr. They were married Oct 31, 1927, at Bream Memorial Church by the Rev. F. C. Brown. Mrs. Frame, the former Thelma Humphreys, is a retired state employee and her husband is retired form Rose City Press. They have five Children: Ralph Frame Jr., Belle; Jo Ann Kittinger, Clio; Marilynn Scoots, Looneyville; Frank Frame, Shippensburg, Pa. and Bruce Frame, St. Albans. They have eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. They request no gifts.

Obituary - Charleston Gazette, Charleston, WV, Published: September 26 2010:

Ralph A. Frame Jr., 82, of Belle died September 23, 2010, at Hubbard Hospice House in Charleston following a short illness.

Ralph was born in Charleston on July 20, 1928, and was the son of the late Ralph Sr. and Thelma Humphreys Frame. He attended Charleston High School, West Virginia University, Commercial Credit Corporation Credit School, West Virginia Bankers School and The American Institute of Banking, of which he subsequently served two years as Chapter president.

He served his country in the U.S. Army as Battalion Court Martial Sergeant and Battalion Sergeant Major with the 17th Signal Operations Battalion in Germany, and was honorably discharged in 1952. Ralph was employed as a manager with Commercial Credit Corporation, a vice president with City National Bank in Kanawha City and was partner in an insurance agency. In the later part of his career, Ralph worked in automobile sales at Bert Wolfe Ford, Stephens Auto Center, and elsewhere.

Ralph was a member of Judson Baptist Church in Belle, where he was a former deacon and Sunday school teacher. He was a member and three term president of the Belle Lions Club, and was elected district governor of the West Virginia Lions District, 29-0.

In addition to his parents, Ralph Sr. and Thelma, Ralph was preceded in death by his maternal grandparents, Charles and Bessie Humphreys; sisters, Marilynn Stotts and Jo Ann Kittinger; sister-in-law, Kathryn Sampson; brother-in-law, J. M. "Monty" Sampson; and parents-in-law, John S. "Pete" and Belle Harmon.

Surviving are his beloved wife of 57 years, Mary Jane Frame; son, R. Anthony "Tony" Frame of Belle and partner Patricia Fink of Dunbar; brothers, Bruce Frame and wife Ruth of St. Albans, and Frank Frame and wife Loretta of Chambersburg, Pa. Ralph is also survived by many dear nieces and nephews and their families, Mike Sampson of Belle, Larry Stotts of Spencer, Sharon Whiting of Charleston, Debbie Kittinger of Charleston, Bobby Kittinger of Charleston, Sean Frame of Allantown, Pa., Sheila Harrison of St. Albans, and Pamela Maddox of St. Albans.

Funeral service will be held at 1 p.m. Tuesday, September 28, 2010, at Fidler and Frame Funeral Home, Belle, with the Rev. Charles Bolen officiating. Burial will follow in Montgomery Memorial Park.

Visitation will be from 6 to 8 p.m. Monday, September 27, at the funeral home.

The Frame family would like to extend a special thanks to the staff at Hubbard Hospice House for their care and compassion; and suggest that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Ralph's memory to Hubbard Hospice House, 1001 Kennawa Drive Charleston, WV 25311.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Obituary - Charleston Gazette, Charleston, WV, Published: 13 May 2005:

Marilynn Irene Stotts, 72, of Looneyville passed at home, surrounded by her family, on Tuesday, May 10, 2005.

A devoted wife and loving mother and grandmother, she leaves behind her husband of 53 years, Larry E. Stotts Sr. of Looneyville; their only son and daughter-in-law, Larry E. and Sandy Stotts Jr. of Spencer; one grandson and his girlfriend, Justin Stotts and Stephanie Fields of Looneyville; one granddaughter, Laura Kay of Spencer; three brothers, Ralph Frame of Belle, Frank Frame of Chambersburg, Pa., and Bruce Frame of St. Albans.

She was preceded in death by her parents, Ralph A. and Thelma Marie Humphreys Frame Sr.; and one sister, JoAnn Kittinger.

She was a member of the Henry's Fork Baptist Church, Tariff, and an avid member of the Democratic Party.

A funeral service will be conducted at 11 a.m. Saturday, May 14 at the John H. Taylor Funeral Home, Spencer, with Pastor Bill Jones officiating. Burial will be in the Clover Cemetery, Clover.

Friends may call at the funeral home from 6 to 8 p.m. on Friday.

REGISTRATION CARD, 2291, Number 98

George Godby; Address: ___St Labans W.Va; Age: 24 yrs; Birth Date: 28 Dec 1894; Where Born: Charleston WVa; U.S. Citizen: Natural born; Occupation: Loco[motive] Fireman; Employer's Name: Chesapeake & Ohio [RR]; Employers Address: Charleston WV; Dependents: Wife; Single or Married: __; Race: Caucasian; Military Service: no; Do you claim exemption from draft (explain grounds): __

signed: George Godby

Ancestry.com. West Virginia,Find A Grave Index, 1780-2012 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2012 - George W Godby:

• Birth: Dec. 28, 1894 in West Virginia, USA, Death: Nov. 9, 1962 in Cabell County, West Virginia, USA; Burial: Cunningham Memorial Park, Saint Albans, Kanawha County, West Virginia, USA.

• Spouse: Julia C Johnson Godby (1896 - 1983).

OBITUARY - Sunday Gazette Mail, Charleston WV, 11 Nov. 1962:

George W. Godby, - Services will be conducted at 2 p.m. in Bartlett Funeral Home at St. Albans by Rev. George M. Newell. Burial will be in Cunningham Memorial Park at St. Albans.

Mr. Godby, 67, of 601 Fifth Ave. died Friday in C&O Hospital at Huntington after a short illness. He was an engineer and 46 year employee of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway and member of Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Engineers.

Surviving are his widow, Julia; three sons, George E. of East Lansing, Mich., Glen S. and John W. both of St. Albans; three daughters, Mrs. Barbara Davis of St. Albans, Mrs. Lois Chapman of Scott Depot and Mrs. Mary Starkey of Louisville, Ky.; five brothers, Roy, Joseph and Harley all of Charleston, Bill of Dunbar and Carl of Madison; three sisters, Mrs. Nell Tully and Mrs. Macel Tate both of Charleston and Mrs. Bess Robinson of South Charleston; and 18 grandchildren.

The body is at the funeral home.

George parents were Samuel Okey Godby and Mary Alice Price. George married Julia Johnson on Aug. 24, 1916 in St. Albans, Kanawha Co., WV by Rev. J.M. Carter.

Created by: Pj, Record added: Mar 15, 2012; Find A Grave Memorial# 86821371

Ancestry.com Obituary Collection - Elizabethton Star, Elizabethton, Tennessee, (Nov/1/2003):

MADISON, W.Va. -- Genevieve Eastep Price, 81, a lifelong resident of Madison, died Friday, April 27, 2001, following a short illness.

Mrs. Price was born February 14, 1920. She was the daughter of the late Jess and Clayte Eastep and was also preceded in death by her husband, Ray C. Price, three grandchildren, Ashley and Aaron Price and Nicole Styers, a sister, Irene Bender, and a brother, Jess Eastep Jr.

Mrs. Price was a member of the Madison United Methodist Church where she formerly taught Sunday School. She was a member of the Madison Junior Women's Club, Wildwood Garden Club, and Flowermore Garden Club. She was a homemaker.

Survivors include three daughters, Sandra P. Casteel, Elizabethton, Tenn., Linda L. Price, Dunbar, and Mrs. David (Wilma) Styers, Camp Creek and Princeton; two sons, Lloyd D. Price, St. Albans, and the Rev. Gary R. Price, Akron, Ohio; five sisters, Patsy McCollum, E. Alton, Ill., Peggy McCormick, Ripley, Hazel McCollum and Dessie Kinder, both of Ridgeview, and Pauline Miller, St. Albans; two brothers, Harry Eastep, Boynton Beach, Fla., and Phillip E. Eastep, Ridgeview; 28 grandchildren; 29 great-grandchildren; four great-great-grandchildren; a special lifelong friend, Margaret Midkiff Buchko, Marmet; and a special nephew, Austin Price, Madison.

Visitation will be from 5 to 7 p.m. Sunday, April 29, at Handley Funeral Home in Danville. A celebration of Mrs. Price's life will be shared by family and friends at 7 p.m. There will be a private graveside service at Boone Memorial Park in Madison on Monday, April 30.

Handley Funeral Home, Box 175, Danville, W.Va., is in charge of arrangements.

Obituary - Charleston Daily Mail, Charleston WV:

Katie Mae (George) Hill, 89, of Petersburg, formerly a resident of South Charleston, died Jan. 7, 2014, at Grant County Nursing Home.

She was born Feb. 10, 1924, in Olcott, to Rome and Sarah George. She was preceded in death by her husband, Freddie Hill; brothers, James and Paul George; and sisters, Genevieve Myers and Ruth Villane.

She was retired from PenneyFare Supermarket and was a member of Spring Hill Baptist Church. She was a "Rosie the Riveter," having spent World War II working at the Naval Ordnance and Armor Plant in South Charleston.

Surviving are her children, Lynn (Roger) Foley of Petersburg, Brad Hill of Gaithersburg, Md., and Bobbie Moore of Sandia Park, N.M.; grandchildren, Julie (Danny) Riggleman of Capon Bridge, Susan (Bryan Stealey) Chipley of Morgantown, Heather (Nicolas Vule Chaves) Hill of Miami, Fla., Christian (Tina) Hill of Poca, Jeremy (Elizabeth) Hill of Georgetown, Mass., Eve Hill of Gaithersburg, Md., Katie Moore of Fayetteville and Emily Moore of Washington, D.C.; great-grandchildren, Annelies Stealey, Julian Stealey, Adam Riggleman, Ben Riggleman, Christian Hill II, Stanton Hill, Ayla Hill, Jacob Hill and Madelynn Brown; sister, Wanda (Wilmer) Creech of Alum Creek; and brother, Bill (Ruth) George of Arizona.

At her request, she has been cremated. Inurnment will be private in Cunningham Memorial Park, St. Albans.

Memorials may be made to Mountaineer Food Bank, 484 Enterprise Drive, Gassaway, WV 26624 (www.mountaineerfoodbank.org).

Federal Judiciary Center, History of the Federal Judiciary, Biographical Directory of Federal Judges,

Hall, Kenneth Keller,

Born February 24, 1918, in Greenview, WV; Died July 8, 1999, in Charleston, WV.

Federal Judicial Service:

• Judge, U. S. District Court, Southern District of West Virginia; Nominated by Richard M. Nixon on November 22, 1971, to a seat vacated by John A. Field, Jr.; Confirmed by the Senate on December 1, 1971, and received commission on December 6, 1971. Service terminated on September 26, 1976, due to appointment to another judicial position.

• Judge, U. S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit; Nominated by Gerald Ford on August 26, 1976, to a seat vacated by John A. Field, Jr.; Confirmed by the Senate on September 1, 1976, and received commission on September 3, 1976. Assumed senior status on February 24, 1998. Service terminated on July 8, 1999, due to death.

Education:

West Virginia University College of Law, J.D., 1948.

Professional Career:

U.S. Naval Reserve, 1942-1945.

Private practice, Madison, West Virginia, 1948-1953.

Mayor, Madison, West Virginia, 1949-1952.

Judge, West Virginia 25th Judicial Circuit, Madison, West Virginia, 1953-1969.

Private practice, Madison, West Virginia, 1969-1970.

Hearing Examiner, Bureau of Hearings and Appeals, Social Security Administration, Charleston, West Virginia, 1970-1971.

Ancestry.com - Obituary Collection - The Charleston Gazette, Charleston WV, 13 Aug 1998:

MISSOURI CITY, Texas - Earl A. Stone, 87, of Missouri City, formerly of St. Albans, W.Va., died Aug. 10, 1998, in Mariner Health of First Colony after a long illness.

He was a retired transportation foreman for Appalachian Power Co. and a former member and deacon of First Baptist Church, St. Albans. He attended Morris Harvey College and was a past president of the Lions Club and a member of the Junior Order of United American Mechanics.

Surviving: wife, Judy A.; daughters, Laura A. Konrad of Missouri City, Mary Lu Duke of Marietta, Ga.; foster brother, Everett W. Stone of Hialeah, Fla.; one grandaughter; two great-grandchildren.

Service will be 10 a.m. Friday at Bartlett-Chapman Funeral Home, St. Albans, with the Rev. John D. Elliott officiating. Burial will be in Cunningham Memorial Park, St. Albans. Friends may call from 6 to 7:30 p.m. today at the funeral home.

Ancestry.com - Obituary Collection - The Charleston Gazette, Charleston WV, 2 Aug 2004:

MISSOURI CITY, Texas - Judy Alice Bowles Stone, 93, of Missouri City, Texas, formerly of St. Albans, died July 29, 2004.

Born in Paradise, W.Va., she was a graduate of St. Albans High School Class of 1930, attended Marshall College, was a member of the Order of the Eastern Star, and was an avid quilter. She was a member and deaconess of the First Baptist Church of St. Albans, where she also was a member of the Gleam Sunday School class. She was preceded in death by her husband of 65 years, Earl A. Stone; and her brother, Roy Bowles.

Surviving are her daughters, Laura Stone Konrad and her husband, Ken, of Missouri City, Texas, and Mary Lu Stone Duke and her husband, Jack, of Marietta, Ga.; her sister, Frances Bowles Workman Cathy and her husband, James, of Victoria, Texas; her granddaughter, Kimberly Konrad Wilkerson and her husband, Kirk, of San Diego, Calif.; and her great-grandchildren, Kristopher Wilkerson, serving in the United States Navy on the U.S.S. Jacinto in Norfolk, Va., and Kali Kay Wilkerson of El Lago, Texas.

Service will be 11 a.m. Tuesday, August 3, 2004, at Bartlett-Chapman Funeral Home, 409 Sixth Avenue, St. Albans, with the Rev. Joel Harpold officiating. Burial will be in Cunningham Memorial Park, St. Albans.

Friends may call one hour prior to the service at the funeral home.

Ancestry.com - Obituary Collection - The Charleston Gazette, (Dec/31/2006):

Emil A. Wheatley, 95, of Danville, passed away Dec. 29, 2006. He was a kind loving and devoted father.

Emil was the oldest of eight siblings, three of whom are still living. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Alice VandeLinde Wheatley and their daughters, Janet Wheatley Pfeil and Juanita Wheatley Peters.

He was a DuPont retiree with over 30 years of service, a member of Olive Branch Missionary Baptist Church and International Order of Odd Fellows. He was a member of Boone County Genealogy Society. He was proud of his family and their accomplishments. He was always willing to lend a helping hand and was a kind, generous man who will be missed by all who knew him.

He is survived by his second wife, Lucille Gillenwater Price Wheatley who gave him loving attention and care during their seven years of marriage; his son, Dr. Edward Wheatley and his wife, Helena, of Charleston. Other survivors include three devoted stepdaughters, Carol Sue DeVere and her husband, Robert, Kathy Keller of Charleston, and Phyllis Casey of Huntington; six grandchildren, Brian Edward Wheatley and wife, Mary Catherine, of High Point, N.C., Elizabeth Anne Wheatley of Charleston, Susan Peters Fitzpatrick and husband, Robert, of Plainfield, Ind., Katherine Peters Martinez and husband, Al, of New Albany, Ohio, Patrick Pfeil and wife, Jessica, of Westport, Conn., Richard Pfeil of New York, N.Y.; seven great-grandchildren, Tristan, Ashley, Taylor, Elisa, Henry John, Mary Ellen, Margaret Elizabeth; five stepgrandchildren, Nicholas Keller, Benjamin DeVere and Michael Casey, all of Charleston, Melissa Holland of Maryland, Jerald Casey of Ripley; four step great-grandchildren; his sisters, Nelda Ball and Mina Ball; one brother, Phil Wheatley; and several living nieces and nephews.

Funeral service will be 2 p.m. Monday, Jan. 1 at Handley Funeral Home, Danville, with the Rev. James Sheets officiating. Burial will follow at Memory Gardens, Madison.

In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Olive Branch Missionary Baptist Church, Turtle Creek.

Friends may call one hour prior to the service at the funeral home.

Ancestry.com - Obituary Collection - The Charleston Gazette, (March 26, 1999)

O.V. "Dick" VandeLinde, 72, of Charleston died March 23, 1999, in Memorial Division, CAMC, after a short illness.

He was director of Erase Foundation, president of Mountain Tamers Inc. and VandeLinde Inc., co-founder and executive director of the West Virginia Surface Mining Association, a former employee of the Division of Natural Resources, a Boone County schoolteacher and also taught two years in East Africa. He was with the U.S. Aid to Foreign Countries through West Virginia University, received a bachelor's degree in vocational agriculture and a master's degree in education from West Virginia University. He was a Navy veteran of World War II, on the board of directors of the Fellowship Hall, Greensboro, N.C., was a member of the West Virginia Surface Mining Old-Timers, president of the founding board of CARES and a member of Village Chapel Presbyterian Church, Kanawha City.

Surviving: wife, Alice Ann VandeLinde; daughters, Barbara V. Farudi of Martinsburg, Wanda V. Mouser of Clifton, Va., Melissa R. Shamblin of Cary, N.C.; sons, David L. VandeLinde of Dunbar, Sean S. Rhodes of Los Angeles; brother, Frank VandeLinde of Brunswick, Ga.; 12 grandchildren.

Memorial service will be 11 a.m. Saturday at Village Chapel Presbyterian Church, Kanawha City, with the Rev. W.F. Mansell Jr. officiating. The body was donated to the Human Gift Registry at West Virginia University. Friends may call one hour prior to service at the church. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Kanawha Valley Fellowship Home, 1107 Virginia St. E., Charleston, WV 25301, or a charity of choice.

Ancestry.com. Web: West Virginia, Find A Grave Index, 1788-2011 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2012 - C. A. "Tom" VandeLinde

• Birth: Apr. 27, 1915; Death: Nov. 8, 2002; Burial: Boone Memorial Park, Madison, Boone County, West Virginia, USA.

OBITUARY:

C.A. 'Tom' VandeLinde, 87, of Madison, died November 8, 2002.

Born April 27, 1915 in Madison, he was the son of the late Henry C. and Annie Miller VandeLinde. He was also preceded in death by his wife, Nellie G. Camp VandeLinde.

He was retired as a heavy equipment operator engineers union in Washington D.C. and he was an Army Airforce Veteran of World War II serving in the Pacific theater.

Surviving: son, Tommy Allen VandeLinde of Virginia Beach, VA; daughter, Anna Mae Furman Vandelinde of Daleville, VA; stepson, Lawrence Vincent of Columbia, SC; six grandchildren; two great grandchildren; two adopted great grandchildren.

Service was 1 p.m. Monday at Stevens Funeral Home with Rev. Tom Bias officiating.

Burial was in Boone Memorial Park.

Created by: Bonita; Record added: Oct 06, 2007; Find A Grave Memorial# 21987588
